title_sort: walt whitman to john burroughs, 20 august [1879]
title: Walt Whitman to John Burroughs, 20 August [1879]
text: 431 Stevens StreetCamden N JAug 20Dear John Burroughs,Postal of 18th just rec'dreceived, & glad enough to hear from you all—the interval has been a long one—I supposed you were off some where—Nothing special with me—After I returned from N Y middle of June, went down to my Jersey farm friends a couple of weeks—but they have moved into a new place, superior for their purposes, but to me the attraction had ceased, & I left—Otherwise have been here in Camden all summer (I feel now as though I ought to have gone up & room'd in your house & boarded with Smith the last two months)—I still keep well—about the same as when you last saw me—may be a trifle ruggeder yet—All here well—I enclose you two letters from Mrs Gilchrist in England, & one from my friend Mrs Botta, may interest you—I shall send you papers to-morrow—Weather fine yesterday & to-day here—& I am out enjoying it—(after fair days of pouring rain)I often see your name, & extracts, (sometimes quite long ones) in the papers hereabouts—Love to 'Sula—Walt WhitmanThat Del:Delaware river boat trip? Did it come off? You know I have heard nothing about it since— Walt Whitman to John Burroughs, 20 August [1879]
